Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: GENIE Modeling of Paleogene Hyperthermals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program?s awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise, and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four month research fellowship by Dr. Sandra Kirtland Turner to work with Dr. Andy Ridgwell at the University of Bristol in Bristol, United Kingdom.

By the end of the 21st century, the continued build-up of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere means that radiative forcing of Earth's climate will surpass anything seen on Earth for tens of millions of years. Numerous abrupt warming events (hyperthermals) that occurred in the warm, 'greenhouse' climate before ~40 Ma provide our best analogs for future climate change. During these events, there is evidence for rapid injections of massive amounts of carbon into the oceans and atmosphere, accompanied by intense warming and ocean acidification. Characteristics of these events, including their regular occurrence and fast rate of recovery, suggest gaps in understanding of carbon cycle instabilities and feedbacks in a warm climate. To fully exploit the potential of these events to inform Earth's predicted long-term response to fossil fuel emissions, it is critical to combine datasets that reconstruct these events with models that test hypotheses regarding the controls on their occurrence.

This research uses an Earth system model of intermediate complexity called GENIE (Grid-Enabled Integrated Earth system model) to test key questions regarding the mechanisms responsible for initiating and terminating hyperthermal events on a greenhouse Earth. The first objective is to use the GENIE model to assess the fidelity of individual paleoclimatic records in recording abrupt climate transitions. This exercise involves the development of a methodology to improve estimates of the size of these events by incorporating and systematically assessing the biases that influence preservation of event size and shape in the geologic record. The second objective is to add key model capabilities to GENIE that will 1) enable study of how variations in Earth's orbit impact the timing and size of hyperthermal events and 2) test the role of carbon sources that are not yet explicitly included in existing carbon cycle-climate models.

In addition to her research, Dr. Kirtland Turner is interested in the broader social and political implications of paleoclimatology and carbon cycle-climate modeling. She hopes to use results from her reconstruction and modeling of hyperthermal events to educate the public and policymakers about the true lifetime of fossil fuel CO2 emissions and characteristics of a warm world. Finally, this research will help develop new international collaborations between the PI, collaborators at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, CA (Dr. Richard Norris? research group), and Dr. Ridgwell?s research group at the University of Bristol, U.K.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to assess hyperthermal events that occurred during the extreme global warmth of the early Cenozoic Era. Hyperthermals are abrupt episodes of global warming coincident with evidence for greenhouse-gas loading of the atmosphere and oceans. The two most common lines of evidence for this greenhouse gas loading are a negative excursion in the carbon isotope composition of both inorganic and organic forms of carbon and the dissolution of seafloor carbonates. As such, they are excellent analogs for understanding the long-term consequences of carbon release to the Earth system. The most well-known and largest hyperthermal is the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM) occurring approximately 56 million years ago.

In this project, I used the Earth system model GENIE to compare a modeled response to carbon release and warming with available geochemical data across hyperthermals. The GENIE model includes a 3D dynamic ocean model coupled to a simplified energy and moisture balance atmosphere, a model for the biogeochemical cycling of carbon cycle relevant elements and isotopes, and sediment and weathering models. Due to its relatively low spatial resolution and simplified representation of the atmosphere, GENIE is an excellent tool for studying past changes in climate operating over thousands to hundreds of thousands of years.

First, as published in Kirtland Turner and Ridgwell, 2013, in Paleoceanography, I utilized the sediment model in GENIE to assess how records of environmental change derived from marine sediment cores may fail to accurately represent of processes in the atmosphere and oceans because of sediment mixing through the action of benthic organisms (bioturbation) and chemical dissolution of carbonates. I utilized the difference between the atmosphere and ocean versus sediment core representations of an abrupt input of isotopically depleted carbon to the atmosphere to iteratively correct the atmospheric forcing necessary to generate a model sediment core record consistent with available data. These experiments demonstrated that the carbon forcing required to generate hyperthermals may be considerably greater in rate and magnitude than reading marine sediment records at ‘face value’ would imply.

Next, I conducted an extensive set of experiments using GENIE, as published in Kirtland Turner and Ridgwell, 2016, in Earth and Planetary Science Letters, to trace physical and chemical responses of the Earth system to varying rates of carbon input. For instance, I developed an empirical relationship to relate the different size of carbon isotope excursions seen in various carbon reservoirs to the rate at which carbon enters the atmosphere. These experiments provided a framework for interpreting the rate of onset of past hyperthermals. Using the PETM as a case study, and applying this relationship between relative excursion size and carbon input rate to PETM records from terrestrial and marine environments, I suggested that the onset of the PETM (i.e. the duration of carbon emissions which drove the negative carbon isotopic excursion) occurred in less than 3000 years.

In addition to these key outcomes, this project has supported further work of mine in evaluating hyperthermal events using the GENIE model. Key areas of ongoing research, including a series of papers in revision, include the impact of hyperthermals on patterns and strength of ocean overturning circulation, the role of orbital forcing in the generation and timing of hyperthermals, and the impact of hyperthermals on the marine biological carbon pump.
